title: About Me
text:
Hi, my name is Haley Geringer and I’m a second year with senior standing from Bellevue, Nebraska. Currently I’m a double major studying sports media and communications and advertising and public relations with a minor in coaching at the University of Nebraska – Lincoln.  
As a full-time college student, I work two part-time jobs with other floater jobs here and there. One job is out in Omaha, it’s Goldfish Swim School where I am manager on duty (MOD) four days a week. I can do everything from teaching lessons to running the entire store (which I will say is nerve racking).  The other job is my on-campus job with HuskerVision where I am a camera operator for my designated sports. Since winter sports are over you can see me shooting ISO for Nebraska baseball. You can also see me as a peer mentor for the College of Journalism and Mass Communications and doing freelance photography on the side.  
The minute I tried a journalism class in middle school was when I knew I wanted to pursue a career in this field. Currently, the track I want to pursue is to be a Name, Image and Likeness (NIL) agent for student athletes in college. I know how difficult it is to be an athlete and still make money, so I believe being able to help athletes build brands for themselves is important today. Hopefully, I can get a job with the university to start that path, otherwise I have no idea what I’ll do.  
A little about myself, outside of school and work, I love spending time with my friends and family (especially three of my little brothers). Whenever I get the chance, I always go on a good Target run to debrief after a long day or go on a hot girl walk listening to my favorite music. I have a miniature schnauzer who lives with my grandparents named Bella who is the absolute sweetest.

title: Is Nebraska Baseball The Best In The Big Ten
text:
Looking at Big Ten baseball can be a little confusing since not every university has a baseball team, but that’s no the point. With the teams we do have, how can we tell which one is the best among the rest?
First we can look and compare each teams pitching stats and how well they do on the mound. You have to keep in mind that pitchers have that added extra stress from the pitch clock that could affect how they perform.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)

games <- read.csv("pitching.csv")

totals <- games |> 
  group_by(Team) |> 
  summarize(
    EarnedRuns = sum(ERA),
    InningsPlayed = sum(IP)
  ) 
nu <- totals |> filter(Team == "Nebraska")

bar1 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=totals, aes(x=reorder(Team, EarnedRuns), weight=EarnedRuns), color="grey") +
  geom_bar(data=nu, aes(x=reorder(Team, EarnedRuns), weight=EarnedRuns), color="red") +
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Average Earned Runs"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal() 

bar2 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=totals, aes(x=reorder(Team, InningsPlayed), weight=InningsPlayed), color="grey") +
  geom_bar(data=nu, aes(x=reorder(Team, InningsPlayed), weight=InningsPlayed), color="red") +
  coord_flip() +  
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Average Innings Played") + 
  theme_minimal()

bar1 + bar2 +
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Earned Runs vs. Innings Played",
    subtitle = "How does Nebraska pitching compare to the rest of the Big Ten.",
    caption = "Source: bigten.org | By: Haley Geringer"
  )









Looking into the graphs you can tell where Nebraska does the best. Their average earned innings is the lowest in the Big Ten. That means they are less likely to let a batter walk or get a hit. Average innings played Nebraska stands in the middle. They aren’t the best, but they aren’t the worst.


Code
batting <- read_csv("battingstats.csv")

nu <- batting |> filter (Team =="Nebraska")
rt <- batting |> filter (Team =="Rutgers")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=batting, aes(x=AB, y=H)) +
  geom_point(data=nu, aes(x=AB, y=H), color="red") +
  geom_point(data=rt, aes(x=AB, y=H), color="maroon") +
  labs(
    x="At Bats", 
    y="Hits"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  plot_annotation(
    title = "At Bats vs. Actual Hits",
    subtitle = "With Nebraska being number 5 for batting, 
    how do they compare to number one Rutgers.",
    caption = "Source: bigten.org | By: Haley Geringer"
  )









Looking into our hitting statistics they aren’t looking pretty. The red dot representing Nebraska is in the average area where most of the other dots are. Rutgers on the other hand, they are above Nebraska and every other team in the Big Ten. They lead the Big Ten in at bats and hits creating that big jump between teams. With that being said, Nebraska’s performance on the hitting side could use some work but it’s not the worst anyone has seen.


Code
fielding <- read_csv("fieldingstats.csv")


difference <- fielding |>
  group_by(Team) |> 
  summarise(
    PutOuts = sum(PO), 
    Errors = sum(E))
 

ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=difference, 
    aes(y=reorder(Team, Errors), x=PutOuts, xend=Errors),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
  labs(
    title="Put Outs vs Errors in the Big Ten", 
    subtitle = "If <span style = 'color:green;'>PutOuts</span> are on the right, that's good. If <span style = 'color:red;'>Errors</span> are on the right, that's bad.",
    caption = "Source: bigten.org | By: Haley Geringer"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple()
  ) 









Nobody wants to see a high percentage of errors in their fielding. Every team, including Nebraska, has roughly the same percentage of error in their fielding. That’s good! That means Nebraska is not doing terrible. Put outs on the other hand, that is in the middle closer to the lower end of that. They aren’t getting as many people out with fielding as they are with pitching, but their still getting people out so it evens out.

title: 2023-2024 Top Pitching Prospects
text:
With the 2023-2024 college baseball season coming to an end, lets look into this year top pitching prospects, but more importantly, why are they at the ranks they are at?
Looking into this first graph we can compare the amount of strike outs and hits each pitcher has. The dots that are encircled are all of the prospects who are ranked number one out of all the 305 prospects. You can see that they are lower on the graph which mean they have less hits off of their pitches.
Paul Skenes is probably the best. He has little over 40 strike outs and less than 20 hits off of his pitches. Following close behind him is Tink Hence with a little over 30 strike outs and less than 15 hits.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggtext)

pitchers <- read_csv("prospets2.csv")

toppitchers <- pitchers |> filter(rank == "1")
rt <- toppitchers |> filter(full_name == "Ricky Tiedemann")
th <- toppitchers |> filter(full_name == "Tink Hence")
ps <- toppitchers |> filter(full_name == "Paul Skenes")
nm <- toppitchers |> filter(full_name == "Noble Meyer")
as <- toppitchers |> filter(full_name == "AJ Smith-Shawver")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=pitchers, aes(x=strikeOuts, y=hits), color="grey") +
  geom_point(data=toppitchers, aes(x=strikeOuts , y=hits), color="blue") + 
  geom_text(data=rt, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits+1, label=full_name)) +
  geom_encircle(data=rt, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits), s_shape=.01, expand=.01, colour="blue") +
  geom_text(data=th, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits+1, label=full_name)) +
  geom_encircle(data=th, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits), s_shape=.01, expand=.01, colour="blue") +
  geom_text(data=ps, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits+1, label=full_name)) +
  geom_encircle(data=ps, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits), s_shape=.01, expand=.01, colour="blue") +
  geom_text(data=nm, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits+1, label=full_name)) +
  geom_encircle(data=nm, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits), s_shape=.01, expand=.001, colour="blue") +
  geom_text(data=as, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits+1, label=full_name)) +
  geom_encircle(data=as, aes(x=strikeOuts-.05, y=hits), s_shape=.01, expand=.001, colour="blue") +
  labs(title="Number One Ranked Top Pitcher Prospects ", subtitle="How do the number one ranked top prospects comapre to the rest.", x="Strike Outs", y="Hits", caption="Source: mlb.com | By: Haley Geringer") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )









This graph only shows the groups of the first three ranks since showing all 305 prospects would be a lot to look at. Obviously red is bad and green is good, but what is the point? The farther a part each dot is from each other the better. The goal for each of the pitchers is to have less automatic first bases and more strike outs. The closer they are to each other isn’t really the best.
Look at Jared Jones, the fourth dots down on the chart, his two dots are the furthest away from each other than any one else on the chart. That shows he has thrown over 50 strikes and has let only five people walk this season.


Code
pitchers1 <- read_csv("prospects.csv")

ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=pitchers1, 
    aes(y=reorder(full_name, rank), x=baseOnBalls, xend=strikeOuts),
    size = 1,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "red",
    colour_xend = "green") +
  labs(
    title="Automatic First base VS. Strike Outs In The Top Prospects", 
    subtitle = "If <span style = 'color:green;'>strike outs</span> are on the right,       that's good. 
    If <span style = 'color:red;'>automatic first bases</span> are on the right, that's bad.", 
    
    x="Automatic First Base & Strike Outs", 
    y="Pitcher", 
    caption="Source: mlb.com | By: Haley Geringer"
  ) + 
  theme(
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple()
  )









How does the amount of hits off of your pitches really affect your stats? We can figure that out by looking the grab below. Each of the bubbles below is one of the top pitchers in that column for the amount of games they’ve pitched in. The size of their bubble is determined by the amount of hits batters have gotten off of their pitches. The bigger the bubble is bad for them. All five of them have some of the smaller bubbles so less hits.
You can also see they each have played few games but have quite a few innings under their belts. Tink Hence, Paul Skenes and Ty Madden all roughly have less than 20 hits off of their pitches while all pitching almost the same amount of innings.


Code
inningsvsbatters <- pitchers
kn <- inningsvsbatters |> filter(full_name == "Kyle Nicolas")
bk <- inningsvsbatters |> filter(full_name == "Ben Kudrna")
yl <- inningsvsbatters |> filter(full_name == "Yu-Min Lin")
tm <- inningsvsbatters |> filter(full_name == "Ty Madden")
bb <- inningsvsbatters |> filter(full_name == "Ben Brown")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=inningsvsbatters, 
    aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched, size=hits),alpha = .3, color="darkgrey") +
  geom_point(
    data=th,
    aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched, size=hits), color="lightblue") +
  geom_text(data=th, aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched+2, label=full_name)) +
  geom_point(
    data=ps,
    aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched, size=hits), color="lightblue") +
  geom_text(data=ps, aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched+2, label=full_name)) +
  geom_point(
    data=yl,
    aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched, size=hits), color="lightblue") +
  geom_text(data=yl, aes(x=gamesPitched-.5, y=inningsPitched+2, label=full_name)) +
  geom_point(
    data=tm,
    aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched, size=hits), color="lightblue")+
  geom_text(data=tm, aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched+2, label=full_name)) +
  geom_point(
    data=bb,
    aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched, size=hits), color="lightblue")+
  geom_text(data=bb, aes(x=gamesPitched, y=inningsPitched+2, label=full_name)) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 5.42623) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 18.31541) +
  labs(title="Innings And Games VS. Hits ", subtitle="How does the amount of hits against a players pitch affect their stats?", x="Number of Games Pitched", y="Average Amount of Innings Pitched", size="Hits", caption="Source: mlb.com | By: Haley Geringer") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )









The futures for all of the future prospects are looking bright. They all could a more time and innings before going into the MLB just so they can say they have the experience, but all of them are ending their 2023-2024 seasons off on high notes.
